question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
For some value of $x,$ $0 < x < 180,$
\[\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ \tan x^\circ = \tan 53^\circ + \tan 81^\circ + \tan x^\circ.\]Find $x.$
inference:
**Solution:**
$$\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ \tan x^\circ=\tan 53^\circ + \tan 81^\circ + \tan x^\circ$$
$$\Rightarrow (\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ)-1 = \tan x^\circ-(\tan 53^\circ + \tan 81^\circ)$$
$$\Rightarrow (\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ)-1 = \tan x^\circ-\tan (53^\circ+81^\circ)$$
$$\Rightarrow (\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ)-1 = \tan x^\circ-\tan 134^\circ$$
$$\Rightarrow (\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ)-1 = \tan x^\circ-\tan (180^\circ-46^\circ)$$
$$\Rightarrow (\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ)-1 = \tan x^\circ-\tan 46^\circ$$
$$\Rightarrow (\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ)-1 = \tan x^\circ-\frac{\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ-1}{\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ+1}$$
$$\Rightarrow (\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ)-1 = \tan x^\circ-\frac{(\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ)-1}{(\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ)+1}$$
$$\Rightarrow (\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ)-1 = \tan x^\circ-\frac{(\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ)-1}{(\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ)+1}$$
$$\Rightarrow (\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ)-1 = \tan x^\circ-\frac{(\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ)-1}{(\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ)+1}$$

$$\Rightarrow (\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ)-1 = \tan x^\circ-\frac{(\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ)-1}{(\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ)+1}$$

$$\Rightarrow (\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ)-1 = \tan x^\circ-\frac{(\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ)-1}{(\tan
ground_truth:
Isolating $\tan x^\circ,$ we find
\begin{align*}
\tan x &= \frac{\tan 53^\circ + \tan 81^\circ}{\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ - 1} \\
&= -\frac{\tan 53^\circ + \tan 81^\circ}{1 - \tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ}.
\end{align*}From the angle addition formula, this is equal to
\[-\tan (53^\circ + 81^\circ) = -\tan 134^\circ = \tan 46^\circ.\]Therefore, $x = \boxed{46}.$

ground_truth:
Isolating $\tan x^\circ,$ we find
\begin{align*}
\tan x &= \frac{\tan 53^\circ + \tan 81^\circ}{\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ - 1} \\
&= -\frac{\tan 53^\circ + \tan 81^\circ}{1 - \tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ}.
\end{align*}From the angle addition formula, this is equal to
\[-\tan (53^\circ + 81^\circ) = -\tan 134^\circ = \tan 46^\circ.\]Therefore, $x = \boxed{46}.$
